thread.title: Two hours, $18 million in sales, all sold: mid-week auction fever takes hold
thread.title_full: Two hours, $18 million in sales, all sold: mid-week auction fever takes hold

author: Lucy Macken
title: Two hours, $18 million in sales, all sold: mid-week auction fever takes hold
text:
Techie Mike Cannon-Brookes proves a sucker for fine real estate, twice The problem fuelling ever-rising property prices in Sydney was on show before more than 100 people on Thursday night in the Ray White Double Bay auction room as four eastern suburbs properties went under the hammer. 
Too many buyers and not enough stock saw all four properties sell, totalling more than $18 million worth of sales in less than two hours. 
“The spirited bidding shows that with the limited amount of stock at the moment buyers are stretching themselves to new limits,” was the summary by Ray White Double Bay’s director Craig Pontey . 
Patrick and Tamsin Johnson scored $1,755,000 for their Darling Point apartment. Photo: supplied 
One of those who likely wasn’t complaining was Patrick Johnson, of bespoke tailor P. Johnson Tailors, and his interior designer wife Tamsin Johnson, who scored $1,755,000 for their Darling Point apartment. 
Selling agent Gavin Rubinstein had listed the whole-floor spread this month with an initial guide of between $1.3 million and $1.4 million. The reserve was lifted to $1.5 million shortly before the auction, but still sold for $255,000 more than that. 
The couple paid $1,065,000 for the apartment in 2012, but had redesigned it since then. 
Tailor Patrick Johnson and his interior designer wife Tamsin are selling their Darling Point apartment. Photo: Supplied 
The Johnsons are bound for Tamarama, where they have paid $3.85 million for the family home of Philip Green , until recently the Australian High Commissioner in Singapore. 
Another interior designer to cash in on the current market conditions on the night was Juliet Black, wife of radiologist James Black. 
Black’s recently renovated project on Bellevue Hill’s Ginahgulla Road received offers late last year of $6.7 million and $6.8 million, but instead she opted to put it under the hammer this week. It sold for about $7 million, again through Rubinstein. 
This Bellevue Hill home was bought for $5 million, renovated last year and sold on Thursday for about $7 million. Photo: supplied 
The property last traded in 2015 for $5 million when sold by former AJ Lucas chief Allan Campbell, but had been renovated last year.
